fehler = "1.0.0"

# Der Fehler
[![Documentation](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://docs.rs/fehler/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/fehler/*/fehler/)
Der Fehler is a library to add support for "throwing functions" to Rust through procedural macros. Functions marked with the ``throws`` attribute return ```Result```, but the "Ok" path is used by default and you don't need to wrap ok return values in ```Ok```. To throw errors, use ```?``` or the ``throws`` macro.
Der Fehler provides these items:
### The ````#``[``throws``]```` attribute
The throws attribute modifies a function or method to make it return a ```Result```. It takes an optional typename as an argument to the attribute which will be the error type of this function; if no typename is supplied, it uses the default error type for this crate.
Within the function body, ```return```s (including the implicit final return) are automatically "Ok-wrapped." To raise errors, use ```?``` or the ``throws!`` macro.
For example, these two functions are equivalent:
```
```#``[``throws```(```i32```)```]``
``fn` `foo`````(``x``:` `bool````)```` ``->` `i32`` ````{`
  `if` x `{`
    `0`
  `}` `else` `{`
    `throw!``(``1``)``;`
  `}`
```}```
``fn` `bar`````(``x``:` `bool````)```` ``->` ``Result``<``i32`, `i32``>``` ````{`
  `if` x `{`
    `Ok``(``0``)`
  `}` `else` `{`
    `Err``(``1``)`
  `}`
```}```
`
```

## In functions that return ```Option```
The attribute can be used to make a function that returns an Option using the ```as` `Option``` syntax, demonstrated below:
```
```//` This function returns `Option<i32>``
``#``[``throws```(```as Option```)```]``
``fn` `foo`````(``x``:` `bool````)```` ``->` `i32`` ````{`
  `if` x `{`
    `return` `0``;`
  `}` `else` `{`
    `throw!``(``)``;`
  `}`
```}```
`
```

### The ``throw!`` macro
``throw!`` is a macro which is equivalent to the ```Err``(``$e``)``?``` pattern. It takes an error type and "throws" it.
One important aspect of the ``throw!`` macro is that it allows you to return errors inside of functions marked with ``throws``. You cannot just ```return``` errors from these functions, you need to use this macro.
# TODO
  * Make throws work on closures and async blocks (attributes are not allowed on expressions on stable)
  * Make throws work on Try types other than Result and Option (TRy is not on stable).


## License
Licensed under either of
  * Apache License, Version 2.0 ([LICENSE-APACHE](https://github.com/withoutboats/fehler/blob/67a237309a9e943c9de506ba2748501811f4117a/LICENSE-APACHE) or <http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0>)
  * MIT license ([LICENSE-MIT](https://github.com/withoutboats/fehler/blob/67a237309a9e943c9de506ba2748501811f4117a/LICENSE-MIT) or <http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT>)


at your option.

Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.
#### Dependencies
~1.5MB  ~38K SLoC
  * [fehler-macros](https://lib.rs/crates/fehler-macros "new") 1.0


  *[SLoC]: approx. additional lines of code

# Der Fehler
![Documentation⟨4⟩](https://docs.rs/fehler/*/fehler/)
Der Fehler is a library to add support for "throwing functions" to Rust through procedural macros. Functions marked with the ``throws`` attribute return ```Result```, but the "Ok" path is used by default and you don't need to wrap ok return values in ```Ok```. To throw errors, use ```?``` or the ``throws`` macro.
Der Fehler provides these items:
### The ````#``[``throws``]```` attribute
The throws attribute modifies a function or method to make it return a ```Result```. It takes an optional typename as an argument to the attribute which will be the error type of this function; if no typename is supplied, it uses the default error type for this crate.
Within the function body, ```return```s (including the implicit final return) are automatically "Ok-wrapped." To raise errors, use ```?``` or the ``throws!`` macro.
For example, these two functions are equivalent:
```
```#``[``throws```(```i32```)```]``
``fn` `foo`````(``x``:` `bool````)```` ``->` `i32`` ````{`
  `if` x `{`
    `0`
  `}` `else` `{`
    `throw!``(``1``)``;`
  `}`
```}```
``fn` `bar`````(``x``:` `bool````)```` ``->` ``Result``<``i32`, `i32``>``` ````{`
  `if` x `{`
    `Ok``(``0``)`
  `}` `else` `{`
    `Err``(``1``)`
  `}`
```}```
`
```

## In functions that return ```Option```
The attribute can be used to make a function that returns an Option using the ```as` `Option``` syntax, demonstrated below:
```
```//` This function returns `Option<i32>``
``#``[``throws```(```as Option```)```]``
``fn` `foo`````(``x``:` `bool````)```` ``->` `i32`` ````{`
  `if` x `{`
    `return` `0``;`
  `}` `else` `{`
    `throw!``(``)``;`
  `}`
```}```
`
```

### The ``throw!`` macro
``throw!`` is a macro which is equivalent to the ```Err``(``$e``)``?``` pattern. It takes an error type and "throws" it.
One important aspect of the ``throw!`` macro is that it allows you to return errors inside of functions marked with ``throws``. You cannot just ```return``` errors from these functions, you need to use this macro.

  * Make throws work on closures and async blocks (attributes are not allowed on expressions on stable)
  * Make throws work on Try types other than Result and Option (TRy is not on stable).

advisory.title: `fehler` is unmaintained; use `culpa` instead
advisory.description:
The [`fehler`](https://crates.io/crates/fehler) crate is no longer maintained.
Consider using [`culpa`](https://crates.io/crates/culpa) instead.

crate_analysis.note: Crate analysis performed with stable toolchain.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `fehler` crate simplifies error handling in Rust by introducing the `throws` attribute macro, which allows functions to implicitly return `Result` types without explicitly specifying them in the signature. Additionally, it provides the `throw` macro for conveniently propagating errors. These features streamline error management and improve code readability.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Error Handling with Macros  
✅ **Factual:** The `fehler` crate provides the `throws` attribute macro, which simplifies error handling by annotating functions that return a `Result`. This allows developers to avoid manually propagating errors using `?`.  
❌ **Counterfactual:** The `throws` macro automatically converts any `Result`-returning function into a `panic`-based error handling mechanism, bypassing `Result` entirely.  

---

### Pair 2: Error Propagation  
✅ **Factual:** The `throw` macro in the `fehler` crate is used to explicitly throw errors within functions annotated with the `throws` macro, ensuring seamless propagation of errors.  
❌ **Counterfactual:** The `throw` macro can only be used in functions that do not return a `Result`, as it directly converts errors into exceptions similar to other programming languages like Java.  

---

### Pair 3: Compatibility with Async Functions  
✅ **Factual:** The `fehler` crate supports usage with async functions, allowing developers to annotate asynchronous functions with the `throws` macro for error handling in `Result`-returning async contexts.  
❌ **Counterfactual:** The `fehler` crate does not support async functions, and attempting to use the `throws` macro with async functions will result in compilation errors.
